headline: Skordalia (Greek Garlic and Potato Spread) Recipe
description: Flavored with olive oil, vinegar, almonds, and plenty of raw garlic, then served chilled or at room temperature, skordalia—a tangy mashed potato dip—will give you a whole new perspective on what mashed potatoes can be.
name: Skordalia (Greek Garlic and Potato Spread) Recipe
keywords: skordalia, skordalia recipe, recipe for skordalia
recipeIngredient: 2 medium russet potatoes (about 1 pound; 450g), peeled and cut into 3/4-inch cubes
1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons (90ml) white wine vinegar and/or fresh lemon juice (from about 2 lemons; see note)
Warmed pita and/or bread, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Set cubed potatoes in a colander and rinse under cold water until water runs clear. Transfer to a large saucepan and cover with cold water by at least 2 inches. Season water with salt until it is salty like tears . Bring water to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to medium-low and simmer until a knife easily pierces potatoes with no resistance, 10 to 15 minutes. Drain potatoes in colander, then rinse with hot running water for 30 seconds.

Meanwhile, in a food processor, combine almonds, garlic, 2 tablespoons (30ml) cold water, and wine vinegar and/or lemon juice. Process until garlic and almonds are reduced to a paste. Season with salt.
Spread potatoes in an even layer on a rimmed baking sheet and transfer to oven until excess moisture has evaporated and surface of potatoes is dry and looks chalky, about 6 minutes.
Using a potato ricer or a food mill with the finest disk, mash potatoes into a large mixing bowl. Alternatively, thoroughly mash potatoes with a potato masher in a large mixing bowl.

Stir in olive oil and almond-garlic mixture until thoroughly incorporated. If skordalia looks like it's breaking slightly (i.e., if the oil does not fully incorporate to form a homogeneous mixture), stir in more cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, beating well, until mixture is emulsified. Season with salt, then garnish with parsley and serve immediately with warm pita or bread, or chill until ready to serve.

review.reviewBody: The amount of vinegar/lemon juice in this recipe seems way off. I love vinegary things, and this was way too much. I looked at other recipes for skordalia that had the vinegar in the 2 tbsp range for a recipe this size, but I thought this recipe seemed so well-researched it must be right. I thinking cutting the vinegar/lemon in half would make this pretty delicious. As it was, I spent a signigicant amount of time making something that is rather uncomfortable to eat.

"blending garlic in the presence of acid reduces the formation of its harshest flavor compounds."

Next time I make hummus, I'm going to see if it takes the edge off the garlic by blending it with the lemon juice and tahini before adding the garbanzos. The last several times I've made it I've toasted finely sliced garlic in olive oil by popping it in the microwave for 30 second bursts until it just starts to brown.

For some reason I don't have the option to rate this recipe on my mobile phone browser (chrome) but anyway, it's a winner. I made this for a party as stated and it tasted lovely. My only gripe is that it makes too much because I had leftovers even after hosting two nights in a row (I served other dips and appetisers including the very delicious spicy Morrocan carrot dip listed on SE)

I made this last night & we loved it! I had some very strong monster-sized garlic cloves and just used 2 of them which still left me with vampire-banishing breath. The addition of the almonds was interesting but you can't tastet them in the end result. Are they there for texture?
